ud3.8:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud3.8:1.3: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several mendicants sat together in the in the pavilion by the kari tree and this discussion came up among them:
ud3.8:2.1: “Reverends, when a mendicant who eats only alms-food is wandering for alms, from time to time they get to see pleasing sights, hear pleasing sounds, smell pleasing smells, taste pleasing tastes, and encounter pleasing touches.
ud3.8:2.2: Walking for alms, they are honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed.
ud3.8:2.3: Come, let us too eat only alms-food.
ud3.8:2.4: From time to time we too will get to see pleasing sights, hear pleasing sounds, smell pleasing smells, taste pleasing tastes, and encounter pleasing touches.
ud3.8:2.5: Let us too walk for alms, honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed.”
ud3.8:2.6: At that point the conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.
ud3.8:3.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the pavilion by the kari tree, where he sat on the seat spread out
ud3.8:3.3: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
